page.title: 20Mari Lwyd (Grey Mare)
page.content: The Welsh ceremony of{Mari Lwyd}still survives in Pencoed at Christmas time.a horse's skull, decorated with ribbons and glass eyes, is carried around the streets on a pole by a man hidden under a white shroud. It is carried from door to door, snapping its jaws at bystanders, and only goes away on payment of a fine - and it is said that those who refuse to pay are sure to have bad luck. The Mari used to be a familiar sight in the area until about 40 years ago. The skull was usually accompanied by a variety of characters, including the leader, a Sergeant, a Merryman carrying a fiddle, and Pwnsh and Siwan (or Punch and Judy). Although the Mari was usually associated with New Year's Eve, it appeared in different villages at any time over the Christmas period.
